citation.article-title: Isolation and characterization of Thiobacillus hydrothermalis sp. nov., a mesophilic obligately chemolithotrophic bacterium isolated from a deep-sea hydrothermal vent in Fiji Basin.

p.s: Description of Thiobacillus hydrothermalis sp. nov.
Thiobacillus hydrothermalis (hy.dro.ther.mal'is N.L. hydrothermalis, pertaining to a hydrothermal vent in the North Fiji Basin)

The description of T. hydrothermalis given here is based on the type strain (referred to as strain R3 in this paper) deposited with the Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen, Braunschweig, FRG (DSM 7121).
Cells are gram-negative, motile, non spore forming, short rods 0.5 x 1 μm.
The organism is strictly autotrophic and chemolithotrophic, using the oxidation of thiosulphate, tetrathionate, sulphide and sulphur for growth.
In liquid batch culture in thiosulphate medium sulphur precipitation (when static) and a drop in pH without tetrathionate accumulation occur.
Initiates growth at pH 6-9 (11-45°C; 0-2 M NaCl), dropping pH to 4.8.
No growth at pH 5 or 9.5 or at 8°C or 50°C.
Colonies on thiosulphate agar are small (0.5-1 mm), circular, convex and smooth, becoming white or yellow with precipitated sulphur.
Uses ammonium salts as nitrogen source.
The DNA contains 67.1 mol% G + C.
Ubiquinone Q8 is present in the respiratory chain.
The 16S rRNA sequence shows a strong phylogenetic affinity to the γ-group of proteobacteria, especially to Thiobacillus neapolitanus.
